p: Preventing and treating hepatobiliary diseases with medicinal plants has had a long history. To date, many herbal medicines including Silybum marianum (milk thistle), Glycyrrhiza glabra, Phyllanthus amarus, Artemisia capillaris, Lysimachia christinae, and Lonicera japonica have been demonstrated to exhibit beneficial effects in managing different indications related to liver and biliary dysfunctions without harmful side effects [ 5, 6]. From the hepatoprotective and therapeutic viewpoints, Curcuma longa ( C. longa) deserves clinical attention. According to the TCM theory, the radix (Yujin in Chinese) and rhizoma (Jiang Huang in Chinese) of C. longa are commonly attributed to the liver meridian [ 7]. Accumulating data have emphasized the pharmacological effects of C. longa for resolving pathological disorders in the hepatic, gallbladder, and biliary system. In addition, curcumin, a representative compound from C. longa, was introduced as a promising candidate that exhibits anti-inflammatory, antifibrotic, and antitumor activities which contribute to the treatment of viral hepatitis, stone, fibrosis, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), HCC, cholangiocarcinoma, etc. [ 8]. Due to the low absorption and bioavailability of curcumin, assuming that the effects of C. longa are largely attributed to the efficacy of curcumin might be misleading.
